content.section: Money Flow â€” DHS Capture Risk
content.claim_summary: Internal note states SAMHSA dollars in Arkansas flow through DHS, creating policy gatekeeping and low downstream visibility; recommended to treat as contextual signal rather than an actionable pipeline.

No FYâ€‘2026 compliance determinations or enforcement actions by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) affecting Arkansas were identified.  CMSâ€™s 2025 approval letter for Arkansasâ€™s sectionÂ 1115 demonstration and related federal guidance documents contain program requirements but do not constitute enforcement actions or compliance determinations for FYâ€‘2026.

source.title:
The CMS approval letter for the Arkansas sectionÂ 1115 demonstration outlines program conditions and expectations but
does not impose enforcement actionsã€29633513042789â€ L1460-L1494ã€‘.

content.claim_summary: Engrossed version of Senate BillÂ 72 (ActÂ 776) appropriating funds for the Administrative Office of the Courts for the 2025â€‘2026 fiscal year.  The bill includes appropriations for the Accountability Court Fund ($400,000), Adult Drug Court Program ($1,000,000), specialty courts ($4,500,000) and other programsã€820752699809212â€ L1290-L1466ã€‘.

Searches of the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) announcements and the Arkansas DHS SABG program pages for FYâ€‘2026 found no compliance determinations or enforcement actions.  The available information focuses on grant program requirements and state prevention initiatives.

contain any compliance determinations or enforcement actionsã€694662080385875â€ L862-L870

content.source: Medicaid SectionÂ 1115 Demonstration â€“ Community Reentry
content.destination: Arkansas Medicaid (DHS) â€“ Peer Support Routing
content.statutory_basis:
CMSâ€™s JulyÂ 22Â 2025 approval letter for the Arkansas â€œOpportunities to Test Transitionâ€‘Related Strategies to Support
Community Reentry from Institutions for Mental Diseaseâ€ SectionÂ 1115(a) demonstration requires the state to engage
peer support specialists to help beneficiaries make connections with communityâ€‘based providers and to implement
strategies such as having peer support specialists in emergency departments to assist with discharge and referral to
treatment providersã€29633513042789â€ L1460-L1494ã€‘.  This demonstration focuses on improving transitions for
individuals with serious mental illness or substance use disorder, but the approval letter does not specify a
dedicated funding amount, so the amount is left unspecified.

content.source: Substance Use Prevention, Treatment & Recovery Services Block Grant (SAMHSA SUBG)
content.destination: Arkansas Department of Human Services â€“ Substance Abuse Program
content.statutory_basis:
The Arkansas Department of Human Services describes the Substance Abuse Block Grant (SABG), also called the
Substance Use Prevention, Treatment and Recovery Services Block Grant (SUBG), as providing funds to plan,
implement and evaluate activities that prevent and treat substance abuse.  SAMHSA requires grantees to spend no
less than 20Â percent of their allotment on prevention strategiesã€694662080385875â€ L862-L867ã€‘.  The state notes that
Arkansas is divided into thirteen catchment areas and that UALR Midâ€‘South coordinates services for this program
ã€694662080385875â€ L862-L870ã€‘.  The site does not publish the FYâ€‘2025/2026 award amount, so the amount is left
unspecified in this artifact.
